data.title: ES6 import not highlihted
"Add Line Comment" fault when blank lines involved
data.body:
(This may be specific to Python but is certainly relevant for languages where spacing is important)

If I have some code like this:

```
    if displayName == "":
        displayName = groupName
    description = getAttr(attributes, "description")
    mailAddress = getAttr(attributes, "mail")
```

and I press CTRL+K, CTRL+C, the lines get properly commented out with "# " prefixing each line, meaning that the indentation remains correct for Python's requirements:

```
    # if displayName == "":
    #     displayName = groupName
    # description = getAttr(attributes, "description")
    # mailAddress = getAttr(attributes, "mail")
```

However, if there is a blank line in the selection, e.g.:

```
    if displayName == "":
        displayName = groupName
    description = getAttr(attributes, "description")
    mailAddress = getAttr(attributes, "mail")

    print "||Group name|%s|" % displayName
    print "||Description|%s|" % description
    print "||Email address|[mailto:%s]|" % mailAddress`
```

the commenting goes wrong because VS Code sees the blank line and then assumes that all of the lines need the comment at the start of the line rather than at the start of the code. In other words, I get this:

```
#         if displayName == "":
#             displayName = groupName
#         description = getAttr(attributes, "description")
#         mailAddress = getAttr(attributes, "mail")
# 
#         print "||Group name|%s|" % displayName
#         print "||Description|%s|" % description
#         print "||Email address|[mailto:%s]|" % mailAddress
```

instead of this:

```
    # if displayName == "":
    #     displayName = groupName
    # description = getAttr(attributes, "description")
    # mailAddress = getAttr(attributes, "mail")
    #
    # print "||Group name|%s|" % displayName
    # print "||Description|%s|" % description
    # print "||Email address|[mailto:%s]|" % mailAddress
```

This can break the Python code because subsequent lines need to be at the same indent level.

data.title: I regularly get the error "Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined" when working with VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I recently get a lot of JavaScript errors in VS Code, mostly

`Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined`

but also

`Cannot read property 'getText' of undefined`. They occur randomly during editing of Typescript files and are quite annoying because they overlap the editor area a bit.

I updated to the newest version today but the error persists. I also deleted the app in the Mac Applications folder and reinstalled it without any luck. Restarting the app didn't help, also restarting the computer.

Can you help?

**Environment:**
- Mac OS X with El Capitan and newest update
- VS Code Version 0.10.8 (0.10.8

![screen shot 2016-02-09 at 12 40 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2170127/12915267/62c124b8-cf2a-11e5-9ba7-e8014a954870.png)

data.title: Does not prompt the "value" property for "document.getElementById("inp").value"
Make debug hover extensible
data.body:
It would make sense to be able to extend functionality and behavior of the debugger also in the frontend. In my specific case, I wish to **hover a global variable** and have it (through https://github.com/WebFreak001/code-debug) send a simple `p Module_Variable` to my target hardware over remote GDB.

Similar to how Watch does it:

![gdb_remote_debug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1297882/12913777/06060fee-cf21-11e5-99f8-b30754412020.gif)

Following from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2745:

> When remote debugging (GDB in my case) and not being able to breakpoint, it would be super helpful to be able to read variables on the fly (e.g. with hover). The workflow of adding variables to Watch takes forever in comparison and doesn't continuously update.
> 
> For reference, this works in Eclipse where hover polls variables between breakpoints.

.

> Agreed, this would of course only make sense on global variables. My colleague has written a GDB bridge for our embedded development and then uses a GDB plugin to poll global variables using hover (I'll double check which plugin).
> 
> As I'm an embedded developer working mainly with C, a simple p Module_Variable is what I'm looking to send. Then it's up to the debugger (in this case GDB) to lookup the memory address and return me the results.
> 
> This might only be valid for a structural language such as C.

data.title: Function breakpoints
data.body:
- [x] win @alexandrudima 
- [x] linux @aeschli
- [x] mac @joaomoreno

We now support **function breakpoints** on global functions for node debugging. Verify:
- you can **add**, **remove**, **update** a function breakpoints
- program **breaks** on a function for the function breakpoint you added

Please note that we only support global functions that have been seen by node and are defined. This is different than line oriented breakpoints which work even if they are not defined when the program starts.
So you probably have to use the "Reapply Breakpoints" action after you have started the target.

Global functions are "setTimeout" etc. and this: 

```
// global function
foo = function(n) {
    return n;
}
```

data.title: Test mono-debug installation hint
data.body:
- [x] OS X @seanmcbreen 
- [x] Linux @joaomoreno

We plan to make **mono-debug** an **optional extension**. To make a smooth transition we let the user know once and offer a direct install. Have a `launch.json` with type `mono`. Verify:
- you are informed and offered to **install** of mono-debug
- the hint only shows **once** 
- you can nicely install mono-debug from the hint and debugging **works** after the install

data.title: Permission problem?
data.body:
If I run VSCode as **root** from bash on Ubuntu/Xubuntu/Lubuntu/Kubuntu it doesn't respond on startup.
This problem occurred on fresh installs, in VMs, on both of my devices.
However running a quick `chown -R root:root /` fixed the problem (It is a local VM, so whatever).
[Disclaimer: Know what you do, do not copy paste that into your terminal]

Anyone else experienced the same on a Ubuntu based distro lately? On Debian/Arch it works just fine.

BTW: I couldn't install the omnisharp plugin for Atom because of the exact same reason.

data.title: C# project - search for symbol or search for file regularly takes forever and needs to compile
data.body:
unity3d project workspace.  Using cmd-T or cmd-P more often than not results in a very long wait time before completion results appear.  If the file in question was recently opened it's nearly immediate, but if not, it could take 15+ seconds.  This makes it severely limited in usefulness for larger projects.

Can't seem to find option that pre-compiles everything to cache symbols, or continues parsing/compiling while working until it's all consumed.

suggest an option that does just that, such that symbol navigation works more like monodevelop, and any symbol I care about is ready to find at any moment.

data.title: PluginHost crash and no way to recover gracefully

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When the PluginHost crashes, VS Code reports that it has to be restarted. However, one of the prime causes of the crash generally involves an extension that misbehaved. But the problem is that once VSCode produces that error, it ends up in one of two states:
1. VS Code's command palette is responsive. But `ext` commands no longer work (simply keeps showing the sliding icon).
2. The command palette itself doesn't work anymore. 

So, now a restart of VS Code ends up crashing right away due to the same misbehaved plugin. And the loop cannot be broken since the only way to actually remove the crashing plugin now doesn't work. (provided the user is actually savvy enough to identify the crashing plugin without any help from VS Code in non-simple cases). This is quite a serious bug IMO. 

I had to go about removing the data files for it to start working (which again is tricky since vscode seems to maintain the installed extensions internally so just removing the extension's folder doesn't always help). 

Note: The plugin that crashed my vs code to an unrecoverable state was `asciidocs` extension, at the time of filing this issue. 

Aside: After the plugin crash, text editor seems to be working, with the exception of a few control keys like `Backspace`. Hmm.

data.title: Allow extending JSON Schema to JSON file name mapping
data.body:
Files like `package.json` or `bower.json` enjoy the autocomplete despite lack of `$schema` reference in the JSON structure.

I assume it's because those file names are mapped to specific JSON Schemas. Allow this mapping to get extended by user.

data.title: Find Widget doesn't trap focus

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The [latest updates](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates) mention the Find Widget's tab order is improved and I agree! Thanks!

However, unlike full Visual Studio, tabbing within the widget doesn't confine the focus; eventually I end up back in my document and the only way to get back is `Ctrl+F` or `Ctrl+H`. I'm not sure if this is intentional (with all your other a11y changes) but I generally prefer the way Visual Studio does it.

Bug? Setting?

data.title: Cannot find module 'vscode' – where is vscode.d.ts now installed?
Support environment variables when resolving values in settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi,

I was just reading the [latest updates](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates) and it says one can install `typescript@next` globally and then set `typescript.tsdk` so VS Code can use the appropriate version/installation. In a team environment, I'd like to put that setting in our project, something like:

`.vscode/settings.json`:

``` json
{
    "typescript.tsdk": "%APPDATA%/npm/node_modules/typescript/lib"
}
```

The problem is restarting VS Code results in an error:

```
The path c:\Projects\Derp\%APPDATA%\npm\node_modules\typescript\lib doesn't point to a valid tsserver install. TypeScript language features will be disabled.
```

Now the setting needs to be per-person because I highly doubt my teammates have `tsc` installed in `C:\Users\Olson\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\typescript\lib` :wink:

Could we get environment variables evaluated on that and all other settings that involve paths?

I haven't tested other paths, but I see these in the Default Settings:
- `git.path`
- `markdown.styles`
- `json.schemas`
- `typescript.tsdk`
- `php.validate.executablePath`
